p.s: In Act 2 scene 2 of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet the lovers reflect on their newly found love and express concerns as well as vows of love.
While both are rather faithful, Juliet is uncertain and tries to be whatever Romeo wants her to be, whereas Romeo is ready to swear on whatever Juliet asks of him.
Early in the beginning of this extract, Romeo states taht he will do anything he has to in order to reach Juliet because of his love for her.
He uses a personnificationpersonification to empathiseemphasize this, thereby saying that love is guiding him and that what love can do that love dares attempt (l. 68).
He intensifies this further by symbolizing love as an angel that helped him reach her (l. 66) and continues this later on, when Juliet asks him how he found this place.
By the use of he (l. 81), Romeo again personnifiespersonifies love and states that love gave him council (l. 81).
Whenever Juliet tries to reason with Romeo, he gives love as his reason to defy the odds and not even the threat of death can change his mind (ll. 71-73).
The lovers contrast in their way of expressing their feelings for another.
As Juliet tries to convince him to leave so that she knows him to be safe, Romeo wants to show how much he is milling to risk to make their unlikely relationship work.
This, Juliet expresses by stating I would not for the world they saw thee here (l. 74) to which Romeo replies that he would rather be found and die thenthan live without her love (ll. 75-78).
Romeo then uses an antithesis to point out just how much he wants Juliet's love.
This starts with the contrasting ideas of his life ended or his death prorogued that then goes on with the different triggers for these two possibilities.
The hate of the Capulets might kill him but he feels that this is better than the lack of Juliet's love (ll. 77-78).
Here, the reader understands just how important Juliet's love is to Romeo and how chaotic the situation that they are in will prove.
In Elizabethan age, this chaotic circumstance might have been seen as a sign of natural disorder that needs to be balanced out.

Since Juliet knows how fragile their situation is, she asks Romeo not to swear (l. 113) on anything, especially not the moon, which changes constantly and to Juliet symbolizedsymbolizes inconsistency in the same way (l. 111) and wants him to swear by himself instead (l. 114) because she sees him as a godlike person and thereby states that she has faith in him.

This is a metaphor that Romeo has also used in the beginning of this extract, when he calls Juliet a saint (l. 61) and then adds that he will be whatever she wants him to be to be worthy of her attention and love.

Juliet also uses multiple exclamations to show her enthusiasm and her longing, such as the exclamation but farewell compliment! (l. 89), which shows her unwillingness to lie to Romeo or hide her feelings, and O gentle Romeo, if thou dost love, pronounce it [...], which shows her with to finally have certainty and is also a request in which she asks Romeo to be true to his intentions (ll. 93f).

Romeo also uses a contrast ot show just how much Juliet's love means to him and again gives her godlike powers and idolizes her by saying that her gaze holds more threat to him than the weapons of her family ever could and that her fondness of him would protect him of her family's hate (l. 71-73).

This idolization is used to express their faith in each other as well as the intensity of their love that is almost holy to them, which is also a reference at the marriage that is going to follow shortly.

In regards to Romeo, who depicts his love as a guiding angel, this metaphor of religious ideas and divine intervention into their lives can be seen as a means of Shakespeare to express that these two lovers were destined to be together and that if not a god, at least fate put them in this situation, which only enhances the two lovers to keep their relationship going and follow the love that put them together instead of ending their chaotic affair immediately.

To conclude, Romeo and Juliet have different views of their unlikely love but while Romeo thinks that love will help them through everything and is fearless and bold to show Juliet how much he means this, Juliet is concerned at first.

However, she lets him talk her out of her concernesconcerns and they both were religious aspects to describe the love that binds them together, thereby expressing their faith and their firm believe that fate has brough them together and that their love is meant to be.
